rules_detail.title: How to Solve Nonograms
rules_detail.intro_p1: Nonograms (also known as Griddlers or Japanese Crosswords) are picture logic puzzles where you must decode a hidden image using numbers placed along the edges of the grid. Each number represents the length of a continuous block of filled cells in that specific row or column. A fundamental rule is that there must be at least one empty (unfilled) cell separating any two adjacent blocks of filled cells.
rules_detail.intro_p2: The solving process is based on strict deduction: you analyze the intersections of horizontal and vertical lines, gradually filling in cells that must logically be shaded. The game is considered complete when all numerical requirements are met, revealing a silhouette or a pixel-art image. Nonograms do not require guessing; any well-designed puzzle has only one logically correct solution that can be found through the process of elimination.

tips.tip1_text: If a number in a row matches the full width or height of the grid, fill it in entirely without hesitation.
tips.tip2_text: If the sum of the numbers in a row (plus the mandatory gaps) covers more than half the length, you can calculate the 'overlap' cells that will be filled regardless of the exact placement.
tips.tip3_text: This is absolutely critical. As soon as you determine a cell cannot be filled, mark it with an 'X' to narrow down your search area.
tips.tip4_text: If a row or column has a '0' or no numbers at all, immediately cross out the entire line with 'X's.
tips.tip5_text: If a filled cell is located right against the edge of the grid, it must be part of the first (or last) number group for that row or column.
tips.tip6_text: Once you have fully formed a block of cells corresponding to a number, cross that number off your clue list to stay organized.
tips.tip7_text: Once a group of cells is completed, place an 'X' on both ends of it to prevent the block from accidentally being extended.
tips.tip8_text: If a specific number group cannot physically fit into a remaining gap, you know that space must be empty.
tips.tip9_text: Every cell you fill in a row must simultaneously satisfy the rules of its intersecting column.
tips.tip10_text: A single mistake early on can ruin the entire logical chain. If you are stuck, look for a clue elsewhere on the board.
tips.tip11_text: It is often easiest to find hooks in the corner cells or the outermost rows, as they have the fewest placement options.
tips.tip12_text: If the distance between two filled cells is smaller than the minimum block size required for that row, those cells cannot be connected.
tips.tip13_text: If there is an 'X' between two filled sections, it guarantees they belong to different number clues.
tips.tip14_text: If placing a block in a certain spot creates a contradiction in the perpendicular row, that spot must be marked as empty.
tips.tip15_text: Fill in the obvious rows first (e.g., a '10' in a 10-cell row), then move on to analyzing smaller, more ambiguous numbers.
tips.tip16_text: Many simple nonograms are symmetrical; while you shouldn't rely on it entirely, it can often point you in the right direction.
tips.tip17_text: Always remember the 'minimum length' of a row is the sum of all its numbers plus one empty space between each.
tips.tip18_text: Without 'X' marks, the board becomes visually cluttered, making it impossible to accurately judge the remaining playable space.

privacy_detail.h1_p: Our application works primarily on the client side. We do not collect personal data such as your name or email address without your explicit consent.
privacy_detail.h2_p: We use the browser's local storage (localStorage) to remember your settings, such as:
